values.description:
Until now, GUI plugins could only be defined on the `gui.config` file. That was not convenient for plugins which needed to specify topics and services that rely on the world name. This PR adds support for plugins inside the SDF file's `<world><gui>` tag.

---

For now, Ignition GUI plugins are wrapped by an extra plugin tag, i.e.

~~~
    <gui fullscreen="0">
      <plugin name="notused" filename="notused">
        <plugin
          filename="Scene3D"
          title="3D View"
          name="3D View"
          show_title_bar="false"
          resizable="false"
          x="0"
          y="0"
          z="0"
          height="798"
          width="1000">
         ...
        </plugin>
      </plugin>
    </gui>
~~~

This was necessary because SDF would strip the extra arguments within `<plugin>` if it were top-level. I don't have a strong opinion now on what would be the most appropriate way of handling that, so I left it as a TODO for now.

---

I added an example world which has a custom name that is reflected on topics and services:

`ign-gazebo -v 4 -f ../examples/worlds/shapes.sdf`

![shapes.world.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2590050284-shapes.world.png)
values.title: Move GUI plugins to SDF file

summary.raw:
Until now, GUI plugins could only be defined on the `gui.config` file. That was not convenient for plugins which needed to specify topics and services that rely on the world name. This PR adds support for plugins inside the SDF file's `<world><gui>` tag.

---

For now, Ignition GUI plugins are wrapped by an extra plugin tag, i.e.

~~~
    <gui fullscreen="0">
      <plugin name="notused" filename="notused">
        <plugin

          height="798"

         ...
        </plugin>
      </plugin>
    </gui>
~~~

This was necessary because SDF would strip the extra arguments within `<plugin>` if it were top-level. I don't have a strong opinion now on what would be the most appropriate way of handling that, so I left it as a TODO for now.

---

I added an example world which has a custom name that is reflected on topics and services:

`ign-gazebo -v 4 -f ../examples/worlds/shapes.sdf`

![shapes.world.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2590050284-shapes.world.png)
summary.html:
Until now, GUI plugins could only be defined on the gui.config file. That was not convenient for plugins which needed to specify topics and services that rely on the world name. This PR adds support for plugins inside the SDF file's <world><gui> tag.

For now, Ignition GUI plugins are wrapped by an extra plugin tag, i.e.

    <gui fullscreen="0">
      <plugin name="notused" filename="notused">
        <plugin
          filename="Scene3D"
          title="3D View"
          name="3D View"
          show_title_bar="false"
          resizable="false"
          x="0"
          y="0"
          z="0"
          height="798"
          width="1000">
         ...
        </plugin>
      </plugin>
    </gui>

This was necessary because SDF would strip the extra arguments within <plugin> if it were top-level. I don't have a strong opinion now on what would be the most appropriate way of handling that, so I left it as a TODO for now.

I added an example world which has a custom name that is reflected on topics and services:

ign-gazebo -v 4 -f ../examples/worlds/shapes.sdf

values.description:
This caches the data produced during an "EntityComponent::Each" into a new class called a View. There is an upfront cost associated with creating a cache, but the benefit pays off over the long run.

Previously, each call to Each from every System would find all entities that match a set of components. Now a call to Each will be cached, and that cache will be used for subsequent Each calls.

I will handle addition and removal of entities and components at runtime in the next PR.

There is an example program you can run to generate performance data:
```
cd examples/standalong/each_performance
mkdir build; cd build; cmake ..; make
./each
gnuplot -e "filename='each.data'" ../each.gp
eog *.png
```

Attached is output from my PC.![matching-entity.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1834264985-matching-entity.png)

![nonmatching-entity.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3505323985-nonmatching-entity.png)
values.title: View cache

values.description:
While debugging issue #1, I noticed that geometries weren’t being rendered correctly when a link was given a transform relative to the model. It seems that this was affecting the “canonical link” specifically, because the relative transform was being added on top of the model transform, when the relative transform should really be identity for the canonical link.

To test this issue, you can load the `debug_shapes.sdf` file with and without the change to see that two boxes which should be identical will land in different spots without the change.

Before change:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1979105324-Screenshot_from_2018-10-08_15-38-58.png)
‌

 After change:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/832205100-Screenshot_from_2018-10-08_15-40-34.png)
  
 The change in this PR ensures that the canonical link pose is always transmitted as identity.

That said, I would suggest that we reconsider defining these poses as relative to the model transform, since that adds a layer of complexity and confusion which isn’t necessary \(unless there’s some benefit for rendering or other systems that I’m unaware of\).
values.title: Ensure correct transform for canonical link

summary.raw:
While debugging issue #1, I noticed that geometries weren’t being rendered correctly when a link was given a transform relative to the model. It seems that this was affecting the “canonical link” specifically, because the relative transform was being added on top of the model transform, when the relative transform should really be identity for the canonical link.

To test this issue, you can load the `debug_shapes.sdf` file with and without the change to see that two boxes which should be identical will land in different spots without the change.

Before change:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1979105324-Screenshot_from_2018-10-08_15-38-58.png)
‌

 After change:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/832205100-Screenshot_from_2018-10-08_15-40-34.png)
  
 The change in this PR ensures that the canonical link pose is always transmitted as identity.

That said, I would suggest that we reconsider defining these poses as relative to the model transform, since that adds a layer of complexity and confusion which isn’t necessary \(unless there’s some benefit for rendering or other systems that I’m unaware of\).
summary.html:
While debugging issue #1, I noticed that geometries weren’t being rendered correctly when a link was given a transform relative to the model. It seems that this was affecting the “canonical link” specifically, because the relative transform was being added on top of the model transform, when the relative transform should really be identity for the canonical link.

To test this issue, you can load the debug_shapes.sdf file with and without the change to see that two boxes which should be identical will land in different spots without the change.

Before change:

‌

After change:

The change in this PR ensures that the canonical link pose is always transmitted as identity.

That said, I would suggest that we reconsider defining these poses as relative to the model transform, since that adds a layer of complexity and confusion which isn’t necessary (unless there’s some benefit for rendering or other systems that I’m unaware of).

values.description:
Use this pull request to hash out the frame semantics we'll use. There are currently many different places frames and their representation have been discussed. The result of this pull request will be the ground-truth on frame semantics.

This will resole issue #3.

Additional sources frame information:

[ SDF reference geometry](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_design/src/33bc24ee42157acfa3c252ed9195c6639526e177/sdf_reference_geometry/sdf_reference_geometry.md?at=smart_pointers&fileviewer=file-view-default)

[Ignition Physics: Frame semantics](https://osrfoundation.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GAZ/pages/659926/Ignition+Physics#IgnitionPhysics-FrameSemantics)

Once approved, the person who merges this should also do the following:

1. Update the atlassian wiki with a link to this design document.
2. Update the SDF gazebo_design document with a link to this design document.
3. Poke @nkoenig to figure out a good way to make these design documents more transparent to external users.
values.title: [WIP] Frame design document

values.description:
This PR now contains just entity erase functionality.

1. Change `EntityErase` and `EraseEntities` to `RequestEntityErase` and `RequestEraseEntities`. This `Request` prefix indicates that actual deletion will occur at a specific time in the simulation update loop.

2. Added `Server::RequestEraseEntity` to support integration tests, and provide users of Gazebo a means to modify simulation.
values.title: Erase entity [Ready for review]

summary.raw:
This PR now contains just entity erase functionality.

1. Change `EntityErase` and `EraseEntities` to `RequestEntityErase` and `RequestEraseEntities`. This `Request` prefix indicates that actual deletion will occur at a specific time in the simulation update loop.

2. Added `Server::RequestEraseEntity` to support integration tests, and provide users of Gazebo a means to modify simulation.
summary.html:
This PR now contains just entity erase functionality.

  1. Change EntityErase and EraseEntities to RequestEntityErase and RequestEraseEntities. This Request prefix indicates that actual deletion will occur at a specific time in the simulation update loop.

  2. Added Server::RequestEraseEntity to support integration tests, and provide users of Gazebo a means to modify simulation.

values.description:
This is the first breakout of pull request #62.

Callback functions to Each now return a bool. This allows an Each call to be stopped early. For example, if you're looking for an Entity with a Name then you can stop when the entity is found.

One interesting side effect that gtest `ASSERT_*` statements can be used inside the callbacks. So, I switched to `EXPECT` statements. This may result in segfaults when the EXPECT fails. The test will still fail, which is the ultimate purpose.
values.title: Each callback with return value [Erase Entity Part 1]

summary.raw:
This is the first breakout of pull request #62.

Callback functions to Each now return a bool. This allows an Each call to be stopped early. For example, if you're looking for an Entity with a Name then you can stop when the entity is found.

One interesting side effect that gtest `ASSERT_*` statements can be used inside the callbacks. So, I switched to `EXPECT` statements. This may result in segfaults when the EXPECT fails. The test will still fail, which is the ultimate purpose.
summary.html:
This is the first breakout of pull request #62.

Callback functions to Each now return a bool. This allows an Each call to be stopped early. For example, if you're looking for an Entity with a Name then you can stop when the entity is found.

One interesting side effect that gtest ASSERT_* statements can be used inside the callbacks. So, I switched to EXPECT statements. This may result in segfaults when the EXPECT fails. The test will still fail, which is the ultimate purpose.

values.description:
Adds support for planes together with ign-gui [pull request #170](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/170)
and ign-physics [pull request #38](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/38).

The pull request also fixes a bug with the way the pose of model is calculated from the canonical link.

* e654c1e: Adds a failing test showing canonical link bug 
* 4747f2d: Adds a fix by multiplying the pose of the canonical link obtained from the physics engine (in world frame) by it's initial transform form it's model. Note that the pose component of the canonical link is left unmodified.
values.title: Add support for planes

summary.raw:
Adds support for planes together with ign-gui [pull request #170](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/170)
and ign-physics [pull request #38](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/38).

The pull request also fixes a bug with the way the pose of model is calculated from the canonical link.

* e654c1e: Adds a failing test showing canonical link bug 
* 4747f2d: Adds a fix by multiplying the pose of the canonical link obtained from the physics engine (in world frame) by it's initial transform form it's model. Note that the pose component of the canonical link is left unmodified.
summary.html:
Adds support for planes together with ign-gui pull request #170 and ign-physics pull request #38.

The pull request also fixes a bug with the way the pose of model is calculated from the canonical link.

  • e654c1e: Adds a failing test showing canonical link bug
  • 4747f2d: Adds a fix by multiplying the pose of the canonical link obtained from the physics engine (in world frame) by it's initial transform form it's model. Note that the pose component of the canonical link is left unmodified.

values.description:
Added the start of a contributing guide, and added the code of conduct file based on https://www.contributor-covenant.org

The CONTRIBUTING guide will help people understand how to contribute to Ignition. The Code of Conduct should be self-explanatory.

Other Ignition libraries will reference these documents. 

Additional pull requests will add more text to the Contributing guide.
values.title: Contributing Guide and Code of Conduct

Other Ignition libraries will reference these documents. 

Additional pull requests will add more text to the Contributing guide.

values.description:
Distributed simulation handshake between primary and secondary system plugins.

Also adds an EventManager object to give plugins the ability to emit/receive `Event` objects, similar to how it worked in Gazebo9.  The main difference is that Events are no longer static, and are on a per SimulationRunner basis.

The plugins currently get their configuration information from SDF files. Setting simulation affinity TBD.

Depends on: [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/156/replace-explicit-templates-with-variadic](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/156/replace-explicit-templates-with-variadic)
values.title: Distributed Sim Handshake

summary.raw:
Distributed simulation handshake between primary and secondary system plugins.

Also adds an EventManager object to give plugins the ability to emit/receive `Event` objects, similar to how it worked in Gazebo9.  The main difference is that Events are no longer static, and are on a per SimulationRunner basis.

The plugins currently get their configuration information from SDF files. Setting simulation affinity TBD.

Depends on: [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/156/replace-explicit-templates-with-variadic](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/156/replace-explicit-templates-with-variadic)

Distributed simulation handshake between primary and secondary system plugins.

Also adds an EventManager object to give plugins the ability to emit/receive Event objects, similar to how it worked in Gazebo9. The main difference is that Events are no longer static, and are on a per SimulationRunner basis.

The plugins currently get their configuration information from SDF files. Setting simulation affinity TBD.

values.description:
**Depends on** [ign-msgs pull request #78](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/78/update-light-msg-fields/diff) and [sdformat pull request #469](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/469/update-light-dom/diff)

Lights defined in sdf can now be parsed and loaded into ign-gazebo. This includes lights attached to links. Light info are published over to ign-gui using via the SceneBroadcaster system

All world sdfs have been updated to include a directional light.

Example world: `examples/worlds/light.sdf`. Press Play to see the ball with blue light roll down the plane. You'll need the [ign-gui branch in this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/171/extend-scene3d-plugin-to-load-lights/diff) to visualize the lights in ign-gui

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2289420647-ign-gazebo-lights.png)
values.title: Add support for lights

Lights defined in sdf can now be parsed and loaded into ign-gazebo. This includes lights attached to links. Light info are published over to ign-gui using via the SceneBroadcaster system

All world sdfs have been updated to include a directional light.

Example world: `examples/worlds/light.sdf`. Press Play to see the ball with blue light roll down the plane. You'll need the [ign-gui branch in this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/171/extend-scene3d-plugin-to-load-lights/diff) to visualize the lights in ign-gui

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2289420647-ign-gazebo-lights.png)
summary.html:
Depends on ign-msgs pull request #78 and sdformat pull request #469

Lights defined in sdf can now be parsed and loaded into ign-gazebo. This includes lights attached to links. Light info are published over to ign-gui using via the SceneBroadcaster system

All world sdfs have been updated to include a directional light.

Example world: examples/worlds/light.sdf. Press Play to see the ball with blue light roll down the plane. You'll need the ign-gui branch in this PR to visualize the lights in ign-gui

values.description:
**Depends on pull requests:** [sdformat  #470](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/470), [sdformat  #471](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/471), [ign-physics #40](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/40)

This pull requests adds the necessary components for supporting joints. Revolute2 and Gear Box joints are currently not supported in ign-physics.

The pull request also includes a fix for a bug in the way poses were set on links relative to their parent model.

## Example:

`ign-gazebo -f test/worlds/demo_joint_types.sdf`

![ign-gazebo-joints2.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1308458866-ign-gazebo-joints2.gif)
values.title: Add support for joints

The pull request also includes a fix for a bug in the way poses were set on links relative to their parent model.

Example:

values.description:
Remove a lot of code, and a whole directory, by using the `SimpleWrapper` introduced by @azeey on pull request #42.

Now we have 2 "types" of components: those that wrap another class, and those that are just an empty class and whose presence means something about an entity.

It could very well be that we eventually get rid of the wrappers and use the classes they're wrapping directly instead. Let's leave this decision for once it's clear how components will be sent over the wire. (disclaimer, I haven't reviewed pull request #69 yet).
values.title: Use SimpleWrapper for more component types

Now we have 2 "types" of components: those that wrap another class, and those that are just an empty class and whose presence means something about an entity.

It could very well be that we eventually get rid of the wrappers and use the classes they're wrapping directly instead. Let's leave this decision for once it's clear how components will be sent over the wire. (disclaimer, I haven't reviewed pull request #69 yet).

values.description:
Introduces an Init method to the system api, that allows systems to get the relevant SDF information from the <plugin> tag.

Introduces ISystemConfigure, an interface for a system to create initial entities, as well as subscribe to events from the EventManager.
values.title: Create an EventManager to be used on a per SimulationRunner basis.

values.description:
This prevents systems from accidentally modifying the `sdf::Element` pointed to by`_sdf` in `ISystemConfigure::Configure`. Currently, even though `_sdf` is passed by const ref, the objected pointed to by `_sdf` is still modifiable. 

Also added some typo/style changes that didn't make in to pull request #79.
values.title: Change signature of Configure to use a raw pointer

summary.raw:
This prevents systems from accidentally modifying the `sdf::Element` pointed to by`_sdf` in `ISystemConfigure::Configure`. Currently, even though `_sdf` is passed by const ref, the objected pointed to by `_sdf` is still modifiable. 

Also added some typo/style changes that didn't make in to pull request #79.
summary.html:
This prevents systems from accidentally modifying the sdf::Element pointed to by_sdf in ISystemConfigure::Configure. Currently, even though _sdf is passed by const ref, the objected pointed to by _sdf is still modifiable.

Also added some typo/style changes that didn't make in to pull request #79.

values.description:
A header is missing from `SystemManager.hh`, which is causing a homebrew build failure:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64&build=2)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/2/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/2/

I also did some minor cmake cleanup:

* add PKGCONFIG entry for Qt5

* use ign_find_package for gflags

* link to ignition-gazebo with `PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME`

* repeat c++17 fix for cpplint.py to fix incorrect code check warning
values.title: Fix homebrew build and clean up some cmake

A header is missing from `SystemManager.hh`, which is causing a homebrew build failure:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64&build=2)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/2/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/2/

summary.html:
A header is missing from SystemManager.hh, which is causing a homebrew build failure:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/2/

I also did some minor cmake cleanup:

  • add PKGCONFIG entry for Qt5

  • use ign_find_package for gflags

  • link to ignition-gazebo with PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME

  • repeat c++17 fix for cpplint.py to fix incorrect code check warning

values.title: Draft of SDF elements section (<level> and <performer>)

values.description:
`EachNew` gets all entities that have been created since the last simulation step. Likewise, `EachErased` gets all entities that are scheduled to be erased. These methods can be used by a system to get notified when new entities are created or existing entities are erased. The notification is synchronized with simulation cycles, i.e, these are not events. Entities that qualify for `EachNew` or `EachErased` are cleared at the end of a simulation step. Thus an entity is "new" or "erased" for only one simulation step.

This also means that if an entity is created in the "Update" phase, systems in the next "PreUpdate" phase will not be notified of the new entity because the next "PreUpdate" occurs in a new simulation step. Same applied for entities scheduled to be erased.

`EachNew` does not return existing (not new) entities if a new component is added to them. We could add another function for doing that, but I just wanted to make it clear that `EachNew` gets only newly created entities.
values.title: EachNew and EachErased

summary.raw:
`EachNew` gets all entities that have been created since the last simulation step. Likewise, `EachErased` gets all entities that are scheduled to be erased. These methods can be used by a system to get notified when new entities are created or existing entities are erased. The notification is synchronized with simulation cycles, i.e, these are not events. Entities that qualify for `EachNew` or `EachErased` are cleared at the end of a simulation step. Thus an entity is "new" or "erased" for only one simulation step.

This also means that if an entity is created in the "Update" phase, systems in the next "PreUpdate" phase will not be notified of the new entity because the next "PreUpdate" occurs in a new simulation step. Same applied for entities scheduled to be erased.

`EachNew` does not return existing (not new) entities if a new component is added to them. We could add another function for doing that, but I just wanted to make it clear that `EachNew` gets only newly created entities.
summary.html:
EachNew gets all entities that have been created since the last simulation step. Likewise, EachErased gets all entities that are scheduled to be erased. These methods can be used by a system to get notified when new entities are created or existing entities are erased. The notification is synchronized with simulation cycles, i.e, these are not events. Entities that qualify for EachNew or EachErased are cleared at the end of a simulation step. Thus an entity is "new" or "erased" for only one simulation step.

This also means that if an entity is created in the "Update" phase, systems in the next "PreUpdate" phase will not be notified of the new entity because the next "PreUpdate" occurs in a new simulation step. Same applied for entities scheduled to be erased.

EachNew does not return existing (not new) entities if a new component is added to them. We could add another function for doing that, but I just wanted to make it clear that EachNew gets only newly created entities.

values.description:
The beginnings of a differential drive implementation, a lot of the architecture based on a plugin from @azeey's `levels` branch.

A quick comparison of this branch with Gazebo 9 shows we still need to port surface properties:

 |
-- | --
This branch (when Louise sends wrong commands) | ![drifting.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3397408235-drifting.gif) 
This branch (ign-physics with DART) | ![diffdrive_correct.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/4107947625-diffdrive_correct.gif)
Gazebo 9 with ODE | ![diffdrivegz9_ode.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1830473749-diffdrivegz9_ode.gif)
Gazebo 9 with DART | ![diffdrivegz9dart.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1185248290-diffdrivegz9dart.gif)

### MVP TODOs:

Done!

### Future TODOs:

* Parse `<surface>`'s `<friction>` and `<contact>` in SDF (postponing for this PR, since the demo car works reasonably well, we may need to revisit when integrating X1)
* Handle friction and contact params on `ign-physics`
* Add a teleop program to send commands with the keyboard (could be a GUI plugin or a standalone program)
* Add a joystick program to send commands

values.description:
* Rename `SystemManager` to `SystemLoader` (no changes to the files themselves)
* `SimulationRunner` stores a shared pointer to `SystemLoader` so it can be used at runtime (not in this PR though)
* Pass entity Id to plugins at `Configure` callback
* Support attaching system plugins to both worlds and models
* Broke `SimulationRunner::CreateEntity` into several functions which can be reused
values.title: Attach systems to models

* Support attaching system plugins to both worlds and models

values.description:
This PR refactors the `EntityComponentManager` class to be more thread safe, or at the very least, start a discussion on how we intend to avoid race condition between systems running in parallel. It came to my attention as I was working on pull request #92 that only entity erasures are currently thread safe. 

In this refactor, all public member functions that access the entity database variables directly or indirectly must lock the `entityMutex`. All private member functions assume that whoever called them already has a lock. This requires
that we break up some member functions so that all they do is lock a mutex and call a private implementation. It is also critical that member functions avoid calling other public member functions because they might try to lock the mutex again. eg. call `EntityMatchesImpl` instead of `EntityMatches` inside a member function.

I have added a test using the compiler's thread sanitizer. It needs a cmake arg `-DENABLE_TSAN=ON` to be enabled.

This PR does not handle the race condition on accessing and mutating components through `Each` and `Component` calls. I'm working on a separate PR for that.
values.title: Refactor EntityComponentManager to be more thread safe

summary.raw:
This PR refactors the `EntityComponentManager` class to be more thread safe, or at the very least, start a discussion on how we intend to avoid race condition between systems running in parallel. It came to my attention as I was working on pull request #92 that only entity erasures are currently thread safe. 

In this refactor, all public member functions that access the entity database variables directly or indirectly must lock the `entityMutex`. All private member functions assume that whoever called them already has a lock. This requires
that we break up some member functions so that all they do is lock a mutex and call a private implementation. It is also critical that member functions avoid calling other public member functions because they might try to lock the mutex again. eg. call `EntityMatchesImpl` instead of `EntityMatches` inside a member function.

I have added a test using the compiler's thread sanitizer. It needs a cmake arg `-DENABLE_TSAN=ON` to be enabled.

This PR does not handle the race condition on accessing and mutating components through `Each` and `Component` calls. I'm working on a separate PR for that.
summary.html:
This PR refactors the EntityComponentManager class to be more thread safe, or at the very least, start a discussion on how we intend to avoid race condition between systems running in parallel. It came to my attention as I was working on pull request #92 that only entity erasures are currently thread safe.

In this refactor, all public member functions that access the entity database variables directly or indirectly must lock the entityMutex. All private member functions assume that whoever called them already has a lock. This requires that we break up some member functions so that all they do is lock a mutex and call a private implementation. It is also critical that member functions avoid calling other public member functions because they might try to lock the mutex again. eg. call EntityMatchesImpl instead of EntityMatches inside a member function.

I have added a test using the compiler's thread sanitizer. It needs a cmake arg -DENABLE_TSAN=ON to be enabled.

This PR does not handle the race condition on accessing and mutating components through Each and Component calls. I'm working on a separate PR for that.

values.reason: I'm closing this PR for the time being. We'll revisit this when we start running systems in parallel.

values.description:
This PR removes all direct mutable access to components and provides a new mechanism for updating components:

  * `UpdateComponent` updates the component immediately. This is not the preferred way to update components, but I thought we might need such a function in some systems. 
*  `RequestUpdateComponent` schedules an update that gets processed at the end of each `*Update` call. There is some ground work to support update priorities (much like css z-index) as @chapulina suggested. Currently, priorities are ignored and the the last system that requested an update gets the last say.
values.title: New mechanism for updating the value of components

summary.raw:
This PR removes all direct mutable access to components and provides a new mechanism for updating components:

  * `UpdateComponent` updates the component immediately. This is not the preferred way to update components, but I thought we might need such a function in some systems. 
*  `RequestUpdateComponent` schedules an update that gets processed at the end of each `*Update` call. There is some ground work to support update priorities (much like css z-index) as @chapulina suggested. Currently, priorities are ignored and the the last system that requested an update gets the last say.
summary.html:
This PR removes all direct mutable access to components and provides a new mechanism for updating components:

  • UpdateComponent updates the component immediately. This is not the preferred way to update components, but I thought we might need such a function in some systems.
  • RequestUpdateComponent schedules an update that gets processed at the end of each *Update call. There is some ground work to support update priorities (much like css z-index) as @chapulina suggested. Currently, priorities are ignored and the the last system that requested an update gets the last say.
